How should I manage a person with a confirmed learning disability?
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with a confirmed learning disability?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Note: When managing a person with a learning disability, evaluate their capacity to make decisions throughout assessment, care, and treatment on a decision-by-decision basis, and be mindful of their communication needs. Primary care practitioners should regularly review the communication needs of people with learning disabilities as they grow older to find out if they have changed.

  • People with a confirmed learning disability are likely to receive care via a local multidisciplinary learning disability support service/team, who (depending on local availability) may be involved with:
    • Assessment and care co-ordination.
    • Behavioural assessment and treatment.
    • Care management.
    • Community nursing.
    • Epilepsy care.
    • Independent supported living.
    • Mental health.
    • Psychiatry.
    • Psychology.
    • Specialist occupational therapy.
    • Speech and language therapy.
    • Support for children and adults with complex health needs.
    • Support for parents and families.
    • Transition into adult care.
    • Creative therapies.
      • Note: a direct referral to some of these services may be required if they are not available locally under the remit of the disability support service/team.
  • All adults with learning disabilities, and all children and young people who are not having annual health checks with a paediatrician, should be offered an annual health check in primary care. This should be carried out using a standardised template (such as the Cardiff health check template) and can involve (with the person's consent) a family member, carer, care worker, or healthcare professional/social care practitioner who knows the person well. The annual health check should include:
    • Initially asking the person, or their parent/carer if they have any specific concerns — these should be addressed by the end of the consultation.
    • An assessment of general health — may include weight, height, BMI, blood pressure, cholesterol, urine analysis, smoking status, and/or alcohol intake, depending on factors including the person's age.
    • Recording vaccination status and offering any outstanding immunizations. People with a learning disability should have the same regimes as others and are in a priority group for flu immunisation. For further information, please see the CKS topics on Immunizations - childhood, Immunizations - pneumococcal, Immunizations - seasonal influenza, and Immunizations - travel.
      • Note: The person's consent will be required prior to any vaccinations. If you assess that the person does not have capacity to consent, parents/carers will need to be involved in the decision. 
    • Offering/arranging any outstanding cervical screening, mammography, and bowel cancer screening where appropriate —people with a learning disability have the same indications for screening as others. For more information, please see the CKS topics on Bowel screening and Cervical screening. 
    • Asking the person if they are registered with a dentist, how often they see the dentist and checking that they understand the importance of looking after their teeth and mouth.
    • Recording any diagnosed chronic illnesses.
    • A physical health review, including assessment for signs and symptoms of conditions which are common in people with learning disabilities. Depending on the person's age, it may also be appropriate to enquire about signs and symptoms of age-related conditions including cancer, dementia, diabetes, incontinence, osteoporosis, malnutrition, menopausal symptoms, and/or thyroid problems. CKS topics are available on Breast cancer - recognition and referral, Gastrointestinal tract (lower) cancers - recognition and referral, Gastrointestinal tract (upper) cancers - recognition and referral, Gynaecological cancers - recognition and referral, Haematological cancers - recognition and referral, Head and neck cancers - recognition and referral, Lung and pleural cancers - recognition and referral Ovarian cancer, Prostate cancer, Skin cancers - recognition and referral, Urological cancers - recognition and referral,Dementia, Diabetes - type 2, Incontinence - urinary, in women, Osteoporosis - prevention of fragility fractures, Menopause, and Hypothyroidism. If any health issues are suspected, treat as appropriate or refer to the relevant specialist, using clinical judgement to determine urgency. 
    • A full physical examination.
    • A mental health review, including any known or suspected mental health problems. Consider a mental health problem if a person with learning disabilities shows any changes in behaviour such as loss of skills or needing more prompting to use skills, social withdrawal, irritability, avoidance, agitation, and/or loss of interest in activities they usually enjoy. For information on management of mental health problems, see the section on Management of a mental health problem.
    • A review of any known or emerging 'behaviour that challenges' and how it may be linked to any physical health problems. Review and document the presence of risk-factors for 'behaviour that challenges'. For information on management of 'behaviour that challenges', see the section on Management of 'behaviour that challenges'.
    • A review of all current interventions and medication (including that prescribed under shared-care arrangements), such as side-effects, adverse events, interactions, and adherence. 
    • Offering healthy lifestyle, smoking cessation, and contraceptive advice where appropriate. For more information, see the CKS topic on Smoking cessation.
    • Depending on the person's age, providing information and advice about keeping well as they grow older. Tell them about, and/or help them access screening services, testicular and prostate checks, dental checks, hearing and sight tests, and podiatry. Discuss changes that may occur with age. Note: where possible, primary care services should aim to ensure that older people with learning disabilities can see the same GP and other healthcare practitioners, to help practitioners: become familiar with the person's medical history, build good relationships and understand the person's usual behaviour and communication needs.
    • Providing information about other available services, including a care and support assessment under the Care Act 2014 if they have not already had one.
  • Be aware that people with specific syndromes may require tailored and/or additional health assessments. For example, adults with Down's syndrome should receive assessment during their annual health check of changes that might suggest the onset of dementia, such as any change in the person's behaviour, loss of skills (including self-care), or need for more prompting in the past few months. For more information on syndrome-specific health checks, please see the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Health checks for people with learning disabilities toolkit.
  • Other roles of a primary care physician in the general care of a person with a learning disability can include:
    • Prescribing psychiatric medication as part of a shared-care arrangement. When prescribing is transferred to primary care, the GP should have received clear guidance relating to:
      • Which behaviours to target.
      • Monitoring of beneficial and side effects.
      • Taking the lowest effective dose.
      • How long the medication should be taken for.
      • Plans for stopping the medication.
    • Providing information to the person, and/or their carers about:
      • The range and role of different health services (such as health checks and screening).
      • How to access health, social care, and support services.
      • The community and specialist services that are available, and their purpose.
      • Transition from child to adult care. For more information, see the NICE guideline on Transition from children’s to adults’ services for young people using health or social care services.
    • Advising family members or carers about their right to, and/or explaining how to get:
      • A formal carer's assessment of their own needs (including their physical and mental health). Carers should be encouraged to register themselves as a carer, for example, with their own GP.
      • Short breaks and other respite care.
      • Access to family advocacy.
      • Access to family support and information groups.
      • Skills training and emotional support to help them take part in and support interventions for the person with a learning disability.
    • Caring for the person after a hospital discharge — GPs should work alongside the hospital learning disability liaison nurse, and community learning disability team, to provide ongoing support to help the person manage their health condition. It may be necessary to give the person and their family members, carers, or advocate accessible information on:
      • Symptoms and management.
      • Benefits, and potential side effects of treatment.
      • How to take their prescribed medicines.
    • End-of-life care — this may include working collaboratively and sharing information with other practitioners and services involved in the person's daily life, to ensure that:
      • Their needs and wishes, including those associated with faith and culture, nutrition, hydration, and pain management are documented. This is particularly important if the person has difficulty communicating.
      • Any third parties who the person would like to involve in creating their end of life plan are recognised. The person should be asked regularly who they would like to involve in discussions about their end of life plan, in case they change their mind. 
      • The person dies in their preferred location.
      • Family members and carers have been provided (where appropriate) with training, information, and support for example, in medication, pain, nutrition and hydration, to enable the person to die in their preferred location,
      • Key members of the person's support network have the knowledge, confidence and understanding to communicate with the person about their illness and death. This includes being able to talk to the person about symptoms, pain management, and their preferences about resuscitation.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Palliative care - general issues.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Learning disability support teams
  • The information on specific services provided by learning disability support teams is based on information about the roles of local learning disability support teams provided in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Mental health problems in people with learning disabilities: prevention, assessment and management [NICE, 2016a], as well as information from numerous local learning disability support teams located across the UK [Dorset NHS Foundation Trust, 2018], [Homerton University Hospital, 2018], [Humber NHS Foundation Trust, 2018], [Northumbria Healthcare, 2018].
Annual health check
  • The information relating to annual health checks for people with a learning disability is based on expert opinion in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Mental health problems in people with learning disabilities: prevention, assessment and management [NICE, 2016b] and the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Step-by-step guide to health checks for people with a learning disability [RCGP, 2017a].
Other roles of a primary care physician
  • The information on other roles of a primary care physician in caring for a person with a learning disability is based on expert opinion in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Challenging behaviour and learning disabilities: prevention and interventions for people with learning disabilities whose behaviour challenges [NICE, 2015a], Mental health problems in people with learning disabilities: prevention, assessment and management [NICE, 2016b] and Care and support of people growing older with learning disabilities [NICE, 2018a].
